Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ Thickest coating around 300nm and indexes so low as 1.68. ▶ Further increase of the thickness up to 470nm does not improve the behaviour. ▶ Main factor governing the behaviour (thickness and total surface exposed). Porous TiO2-anatase thin films were obtained by sol–gel method using dip-coating procedure onto glass-slides and silicon wafers in order to study the effect of the porous structure on the photocatalytic properties. Titania sols were synthesized using titanium isopropoxide (TISP) with two types of complexant molecules (acetyl-acetone (AcAc) or acetic acid (AcOH)) and different types of pore-generating agents as: Pluronic F127 (F127), cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), polyethylene glycol hexadecyl ether (Brij56, Brij58). The coatings were characterised by different techniques as grazing X-ray diffraction (GXRD), spectral ellipsometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Maximum thickness around 280nm, and refractive index as low as 1.68 were obtained, indicating that the surfactants allow obtaining porous films. GXRD and TEM analysis confirm the presence of a porous structure but not ordered. TiO2 films obtained from AcAc or AcOH with Brij58 and F127 sols present specific surface areas between 28 and 68m2/g. Photocatalytic activity was studied through the degradation of methyl orange in aqueous solution under UV light exposure. Methyl orange degradation increases with the film thickness up to a maximum value of 470nm, beyond which the efficiency does not further increase. The photocatalytic activity depends on different parameters, such as porosity, film thickness and total surface exposed to illumination. Keywords TiO2 Sol–gel coatings Pore-generating agent Porosity Spectral ellipsometry Photocatalysis Methyl orange 1 Introduction A variety of semiconductors have been studied as photo-catalysts such ZnO [1,2], CdS [3] and TiO2 [4,5]. However, titanium dioxide crystallised as anatase phase, is considered the most suitable and thus the most widely used photocatalyst [6] due to its physical, chemical and optical properties. Furthermore, TiO2 is also applied in other fields such as lithium batteries [7], solar cells [8], antireflection coatings [9], self-cleaning coatings [10] and hot corrosion inhibition. In the last decade the interest in photo-catalysts applications [11] has greatly grown, especially in the field of water purification. In this case, the use of TiO2 powder in anatase phase is the best option to obtain a good photocatalytic oxidation of pollutants. Recently, decontamination of organic compounds in air has received much attention. Consequently technologies to completely or partially purify enclosed atmospheres, such as office buildings, factories or sewage are of great interest [12–14]. Deposition of TiO2 films on transparent substrates was reported to be suitable for this application [15,16]. However, slow reaction rates and low efficiency have been reported for dense TiO2 coatings. To improve the reaction rates (photoctalytic activity), porous TiO2 thin films with large specific surface area have been proposed [17,18]. The increase of the film specific surface area is a good way to promote a larger surface contact between the organic compounds and the semiconductor [19–22]. However, the amount of crystalline material, appropriate pore structure, thickness coating and UV light source must be controlled to obtain an enhanced photocatalytic activity [23–25]. In particular, it is important to design a suitable structure with controlled pore size distribution to improve the mass transfer of the contaminant through the porous film. Sol–gel process is an efficient method to prepare homogeneous porous films by incorporating pore-generating agents [26–29]. This technique presents some advantages compared to other methods such as homogeneity at molecular level, easy control of the composition, low sintering temperature, good adherence to the support, controlled crystallization of anatase and good optical properties. Preliminary studies show that surfactants such as polyethylene glycol [30–35], TritonX100 [36,21], F127 [27] or Tween 20 [23,37] used as pore-directing agents, increase the photocatalytic activity due to increase in coating porosity and effective control of TiO2 crystallisation. However, in most papers the pore distribution is obtained through BET method by N2 adsorption, measuring TiO2 obtained in bulk or as particles, clearly different from the pore structure of a coating obtained from the same sols. Indeed, coatings present higher density and thus the specific surface area is usually overestimated. The aim of this work was to prepare mesoporous nano-crystalline TiO2-anatase films using different surfactants (F127, Brij56 and 58, CTAB and SDS), and to study the key parameters such as film thickness, pores volume, specific surface area and total surface exposed to illumination, on the photocatalytic behaviour. Environmental ellipsometric porosimetry (EEP) allows obtaining a more accurate characterisation of the porous structure and to advance in the relationship between photocatalytic properties and film structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Titania sols were prepared using titanium isopropoxide (TISP) as precursor via acid catalysis. TISP was chemically modified by mixing with acetyl-acetone (AcAc) or acetic acid (AcOH) and absolute ethanol in order to control the hydrolysis and condensation reactions. The sols were maintained under stirring during 1h to form the chelate complexes. Then, different surfactants were incorporated to the sol: pluronic F127 (F127), cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), sodium dodecyl sulfate (Lauryl SDS), polyethylene glycol hexadecyl ether P5759 (Brij56), and P5884 (Brij58). The molar of ratio surfactant/TISP was varied between 10−3 and 0.3 depending on the molecular weight. Table 1 summarizes the molar ratios of surfactant/TISP used to prepare the AcAc and AcOH sols. Finally, a mixture of ethanol and acidified water (0.1M HCl) was added drop by drop onto the solutions, up to a final oxide concentration of 30g/L. The final molar ratio was fixed to 1 TISP:1 AcAc/AcOH:40 EtOH:(10−3–0.3) surfactant:2H2O. All the sols were aged for 2 days before coating deposition. Two reference sols, one with AcAc and other with AcOH, were prepared following the same process but without surfactant addition. The stability of the sols was studied through the evolution of viscosity with time, using an Ostwald viscometer (Pobel, 0c model, viscosity range 0.6–3mPas). 2.2 Catalyst characterisation TiO2 thin films were deposited by dip-coating onto glass-slides and silicon wafers. The withdrawal rate was varied from 5 to 60cm/min and they were heat-treated in air at 450°C for 1h using a heating ramp of 10°C/min. The glass-slides used to measure the photocatalytic activity were coated with one first layer of SiO2, deposited by dip-coating at 25cm/min from a sol prepared in a two-step route using TEOS (tetraethoxysilane) [38]. SiO2 coatings were sintered at 450°C for 30min in an electrical oven, obtaining a thickness of ∼210nm, and a refractive index of ∼1.44, corresponding to 98% of theoretical density of SiO2. These quite dense SiO2 coatings avoid the diffusion of Na+ cations from the glass substrate to the TiO2 coating during firing and the possible inhibition of photocatalytic activity [4,23,39,40]. The coatings were characterised by optical microscopy (Zeiss, HP1, Germany) to detect the presence of precipitates, impurities, bubbles or cracks, transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) (Hitachi H-7100, Japan), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) (NANOTEC, Cervantes, Electrónica, Spain) to confirm the homogeneity and porous structure of the films. TEM samples were obtained by scratching the films and depositing the scaled fragments onto carbon-coated copper grids. Ellipsometry and environmental ellipsometric porosimetry (EEP) measurements were performed using a spectral ellipsometer (M-2000UTM, J.A. Co., Woollam) modified with a system that allows controlling the relative humidity (RH) (Humidity Generator HG-1, Michel Instruments) to characterise films deposited onto flat substrates (glass-slides, silicon, etc.). The spectra were taken in the visible region, between 250 and 900nm at a fixed incident angle of 70°. The data were fitted using the WVASE32 software and taking into account a Cauchy model. From the data fitting, the refractive index (n) (taken at λ =700nm) and the thickness (e) of the films were obtained as a function of relative humidity (from 0% to 100%). The pore volume and the adsorption–desorption isotherms were further obtained by considering the Bruggeman Effective Medium Approximation model. The pore size distributions were calculated utilising a modified Kelvin equation and taking into account ellipsoidal pore geometry. Finally, an estimation of the specific surface area and the exposed surface area per 1cm2 of sample were calculated. The whole process is described in the paper of Boissiere et al. [41]. Coatings deposited onto silicon wafers were analysed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) to follow the elimination of surfactants and the crystallisation of anatase as a function of temperature and time. FTIR spectra were recorded in transmission mode in the frequency range 4000–400cm−1 with a resolution of 2cm−1 using Perkin Elmer FTIR Spectrum 100 equipment. Grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GXRD) studies were performed using CuKα radiation in a Panalytical diffractometer (X’Pert PRO theta/theta) in order to analyse the crystallisation of TiO2-anatase of the films deposited onto silicon wafer. The diffractrograms were recorded in the range of 2θ =20–70°, using a fixed counting time of 20s/step and an increment of 0.05°. 2.3 Catalytic tests Finally, the photocatalytic properties were evaluated by studying the degradation of methyl orange in aqueous solution using the films deposited onto glass-slides on top of a first layer of SiO2. The light sources system consists on three UV-lamps of 6W with a maximum emission at 365nm wavelength (Philips F/TL/6W/08, Holland). The measurements were performed using 50mL of an aqueous solution of methyl orange with a concentration c =7mg/L. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 2 using HCl [42] and the total surface tested was equal to 32cm2. The reactor vessel containing the solution was covered with window-glass to prevent solution evaporation. During the experiment the methyl orange solution was maintained under continuous stirring and aliquots of 1mL were collected every 1h. The degradation of the methyl orange was studied by measuring the concentration of methyl orange based on its absorption band at 508nm using a spectrophotometer UV/vis (UV–vis, Perkin Elmer, Lambda 950). A calibration curve was obtained measuring the maximum absorbance of the band (508nm) as a function of methyl orange concentration (0–10mg/L). The extinction coefficient was calculated by applying the Lambert Beer's law. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of the TiO2 sols Homogeneous and transparent sols were obtained for the reference TiO2 sols with AcAc and AcOH without surfactants. Whereas, the sols prepared with AcAc present a yellow colour, the rest being colourless. Pluronic F127, SDS, CTAB and Brij56 and 58 were incorporated to AcAc sol in different surfactant/TISP molar ratios (Table 1). The incorporation of CTAB produces the de-stabilisation and precipitation of the sol for all molar ratio tested. On the other hand, F127 and Lauryl SDS surfactants lead to stable sols for concentrations lower than 10−3 and 0.05%, respectively. Finally, stable sols were obtained using Brij56 and Brij58 for all molar ratios. Thereby, molar ratios of 0.15 and 0.07% were selected to Brij56 and Brij58 these being the maximum incorporated amounts for each surfactant. AcOH sols were prepared with F127, SDS and Brij56 and Brij58 using the molar ratios previously selected. Homogeneous and transparent sols were obtained except in the case of AcOH–F127 in which de-stabilisation and precipitation of particles is observed. The last column of Table 1 reports the selected molar ratios of surfactant/TISP for each composition, corresponding to the maximum surfactant concentration producing stable sols. These compositions are further used in the following sections. The stability of the sols was evaluated through viscosity measurements at 25°C as a function of aging time. Since all the sols are highly diluted, they maintain a constant viscosity around 2mPas during more than 1 month, revealing excellent stability and the possibility of use for long time. 3.2 Deposition and characterisation of TiO2 coatings TiO2 films were deposited by dipping at different withdrawal rates onto glass-slides and Si-wafers, from TiO2–AcAc and TiO2–AcOH sols without and with surfactants, using the molar ratios selected in the last column of Table 1. After heat treatment at 450°C/1h, optical analysis of the coatings showed a smooth, transparent, uniform and glass-like surface morphology with absence of bubbles, cracks or precipitates. Two and three-layer coatings were prepared from TiO2–AcOH+Brij58 sol with an intermediate treatment of 250°C for 30min. An excellent adherence and mechanical stability were confirmed, all the coatings surpassing the Scotch Tape Test. Spectral ellipsometry permitted to obtain the thickness and the refractive index of the coatings at 25% RH considering a glass-slide/Cauchy model. The critical thickness (e critical), defined as the maximum thickness without cracks, was not reached at the maximum withdrawal rate of our dip-coater (60cm/min) by films obtained from TiO2–AcAc and TiO2–AcOH sols with surfactants; thereby, in these cases the thickness (e maximum) is indicated. Table 2 shows the maximum and critical thickness together with the refractive index, measured at λ =700nm in air at room temperature and at 25% RH. As observed the addition of surfactants promotes an increase in the coating thickness and a simultaneous decrease in its refractive index. The incorporation of a surfactant allows relaxing the stresses developed during drying, and thus to increase the film thickness. To obtain thicker coatings, the sol should be concentrated but de-stabilisation takes place in this conditions. Only the coatings obtained from sols with Lauryl SDS show thickness and refractive index similar to the reference coatings. This high index indicates that during the elimination of surfactant by heat treatment, the film collapsed leading to less porous structure. Thus, the addition of SDS is not a suitable alternative to produce porous TiO2 films. The thickest coatings were obtained with TiO2–AcAc–F127, with values around 300nm and indexes so low as 1.68, indicating a significant reduction of film density and consequently highly porous films. Similar results were obtained for TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 and Brij56. Thicker and porous coatings should provide higher contact surface between organic compounds and semiconductor, thus leading to higher photocatalytic activity. The thickness of the coatings was also measured by profilometry at room temperature obtaining similar values to those referred by ellipsometry. The elimination of surfactants during heat treatment was confirmed by FTIR. Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectra of the coatings deposited onto Si-wafer and obtained from TiO2–AcAc, TiO2–AcAc–F127 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 between 4000 and 400cm−1, (a) before heat treatment and (b) after treated at 450°C/1h. In Fig. 1(a) different bands were observed, produced by surfactants and hydrolysis and condensation reactions of TISP. The bands at 665 and 430cm−1 can be associated to the stretching vibrations of Ti–O and Ti–O–Ti bonds [43]. On the other hand, the bands at 1550, 1450, 1350 and 1140cm−1 correspond to C–H vibrations [44,45] of surfactants and complexing agents. The broadband between 3600 and 3300cm−1 is assigned to ν(O–H) vibrations, and the two peaks at 2930 and 2870cm−1, are associated to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of CH2 group, respectively. After sintering (Fig. 1b) only one band appears at 435cm−1 assigned to crystallised TiO2 as anatase phase [46]. All the bands corresponding to organic bonds have vanished, indicating the complete elimination of the surfactants and complexing agents. This study allows establishing that a heat treatment of 450°C/1h is suitable to eliminate the surfactants and assure the crystallisation of TiO2-anatase. The presence of TiO2-anatase was confirmed by GXRD; Fig. 2 shows the GXRD spectra in the range 2θ =20–70° of TiO2–AcAc, TiO2–AcOH, TiO2–AcAc–F127 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 coatings deposited onto Si-wafers and sintered at 450°C/1h. The tetragonal TiO2-anatase phase (JCPDS-00-083-2243) was identified in all the coatings, while rutile phase (main peak at 27.4°, JCPDS 00-021-1276) was never observed. The peak at 28.7°, present in all the samples, is associated to the substrate Si(111) (JCPDS-00-027-1402). The crystallite size (D) of the coatings was estimated using the Scherrer's equation: (1) D = 0.9 λ β cos θ B where λ is the wavelength of K α (nm), β is the quartz standard-corrected full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the Bragg Peak (rad) and θ B is the Bragg angle (°). In our case, the peak 2θ B =25.2 was chosen as the main peak for determining anatase phase. Crystal sizes between 40 and 45nm were obtained for dense reference TiO2 films and 25 and 30nm for all the porous coatings. Transmission electronic microscopy was used to reveal the porous structure of the coatings deposited onto Si-wafer but the absence of any order (not shown). AFM confirms the porous structure and absence of order in the TiO2 (Fig. 3 ). The control of deposition conditions should allow obtaining meso-structure ordered layers. The porosity of the TiO2–AcAc–F127 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 films deposited onto glass-slide at 35cm/min was determined by spectral ellipsometry with humidity control (EEP), as explained in the experimental section. The adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained from the variation of refractive index and thickness of the films, induced by the change of water partial pressure (between 5 and 98% RH) [41]. Pore size distribution can be further calculated using the Kelvin equation. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) shows the thickness (e) and the refractive index (n) of a TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 coating taken at λ =700nm, as a function of RH during adsorption and desorption measurements. At low RH, low values of refractive index (n 700nm =1.73) were obtained, indicating the presence of micro and/or mesopores in the film. When RH increases, the thickness and the refractive index keep nearly constant up to 40%. At this humidity, a sharp increase of refractive index and a simultaneous decrease in thickness is observed, characteristic of pores filling with water by capillary condensation and contraction of the pore walls [41]. After the first adsorption/desorption cycle, the refractive index at low RH was similar to the original one. Similar behaviour was observed for TiO2–AcAc–F127 coating (not shown). Fig. 5 shows the adsorption/desorption isotherms for TiO2–AcAc–F127 (a) and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 (b) coatings obtained using the Bruggeman effective medium approximation (BEMA) model. A reversible type IV-adsorption/desorption isotherm with hysteresis loop was observed, indicating the presence of pores in the mesoporous range (2–50nm). The relative pressure (P/P 0) was maintained constant up to a value of 0.40–0.50. The corresponding pore size distributions were determined from the adsorption branches and using the Kelvin's equation modified to take into account the surface tension, the water contact angle and the presence of adsorbed water layer at the pore surface [41]. Fig. 6 (a) shows the wide distribution of pore diameters obtained for TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 coating with a pore range around 3nm (±0.3nm), and total pore volume of 34vol.%. Fig. 6(b) presents the bimodal pore size distribution of TiO2–AcAc–F127 coating, with pores around 1.5 and 10nm (±0.3nm) with a total pore volume of 21vol.%. Table 3 summarizes the anisotropy factor, coating density, pore size and pore volume of TiO2–AcAc–F127, TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 multilayers. The specific surface area [m2/cm3] was calculated from the slopes β (β microporous and β mesoporous) of the t-plot curve and considering the pore size (ϕ), pore volume (V porous) and an ellipsoidal pore geometry. The t-plot was obtained taking each point on the isotherm and multiplying the fraction of P/P 0 at that point by the thickness of the monolayer (t). To obtain the specific surface area on [m2/g], the density of the coating (P) was calculated from Eq. (2), derived from Clausius–Mossotti equation [47]: (2) n f 2 − 1 n f 2 + 2 = n m 2 − 1 n m 2 + 2 P + n w 2 − 1 n w 2 + 2 a ( 1 − P ) where n f, n m and n w are the refractive indices of the film, bulk material (n =2.4) and water, and a the relative proportion of pores filled with water. At RH ∼0, a =0 and the Eq. (2) becomes: (3) n f 2 − 1 n f 2 + 2 = n m 2 − 1 n m 2 + 2 P Finally, the total surface exposed to illumination (S exp) was calculated considering the S s [m2/cm3] and the thickness (in cm) per 1cm2 of samples (Eq. (4)): (4) S exp = S s × thickness × 1 c m 2 [ S exp ] = [ m 2 / c m 3 ] × [ cm ] × [ c m 2 ] = [ c m 2 ] Table 3 summarises the values of thickness, refractive index, pore volume, specific surface area (S s) and the surface exposed (S exp) for TiO2–AcAc–F127, TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 multilayer coatings. 3.3 Photocatalytic activity of TiO2 coatings The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 films deposited at 35cm/min onto glass-slides with a first SiO2 coating was evaluated by studying the degradation of methyl orange in aqueous solution (7mg/L) adjusted at pH 2 [42]. The effect of surfactants was first analysed for TiO2–AcAc coatings (with and without any surfactant). TiO2–AcAc coating with a thickness of 80nm was taken as reference material and compared with TiO2–AcAc–F127 (140nm) and TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 (130nm) films as a function of UV/vis irradiation time. Slow degradation of methyl orange was observed for dense reference and TiO2–AcAc–F127 films related to TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 coating that showed the fastest degradation rate (Fig. 7 ). Two explanations were considered: the first is related to the different thickness of the dense (80nm) and porous (130–140nm) films; the other is associated with the different surface exposed to illumination (S exp), 1cm2 for the dense reference, 11cm2 for TiO2–AcAc–F127 film and 23cm2 for TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 coating. The higher is the density of the coating the smaller is the contact area between the surface of the catalyst and the pollutant solution, likely diminishing the photocatalytic activity. From these results the surfactant Brij58 was selected for further studies. Then, TiO2 films of TiO2–AcAc–Brij58 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 were prepared with a thickness around 150nm to analyse effect of the complexing agent on the photocatalytic activity (Fig. 8 ). Although the plot shows a rather fast degradation of methyl orange in both samples, the TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 coating presents a higher activity. Since no presence of residual AcAc or AcOH have been detected by FTIR after sintering, the activity differences are likely associated to the different physical–chemical characteristics of the structures generated by both surfactants. TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 was thus selected for further studies. The last parameter analysed was the thickness, and consequently the effect of the deposited mass of the coatings obtained by multilayer process. Fig. 9 shows the results of methyl orange degradation of TiO2-anatase films of TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 with thickness between 160 and 470nm. The figure shows the accelerated degradation of methyl orange from 160 to 390nm (2-layer film); the total surface exposed increases from 25 to 69cm2 (specific surface areas 60 and 68m2/g) and the entire mass of catalyst is effectively irradiated and active. Further increase of thickness up to 470nm (3-layer film) does not improve the photocatalytic behaviour, showing a stabilisation of the activity around similar values as reported in [25]. This may be explained considering a partial collapse of the structure, reflected in a reduction of pore size to 2.5nm, due to the repeated thermal treatments performed after each coating deposition. Consequently, the mass increase does not implicate improvement of the photocatalytic activity, since a reduced portion of the catalyst can be effectively irradiated with UV photons. These results show the key significance of controlling thickness of coatings and surface exposed to UV illumination. The stability of the coatings was confirmed by repeating the photocatalytic measurements up to 5 times after several months of storage. Before measurement, the coatings were cleaned with water to eliminate the environment contamination and dried at 80°C. In all the cases, very similar photocatalytic behaviour was observed indicating the reproducibility of the measurements and the stability and reliability of the coatings. These experimental data permit to conclude that the photocatalytic activity depends on different parameters of the coatings: type of complexing agent and surfactant, porosity and pore size distribution, and total mass deposited. But the main factors governing this behaviour seems to be an enough thickness (and deposited mass) along with the total surface exposed to UV illumination. 4 Conclusions Transparent and homogeneous TiO2 sols were synthesized using AcAc and AcOH as complex agents with different surfactants (F127, Brij56 and Brij58). Transparent, homogeneous and crack-free TiO2-anatase films were obtained with maximum thickness near 280nm and refractive index as low as 1.68 for TiO2–AcAc–F127 and TiO2–AcOH–Brij58. GDXR and FTIR confirmed that all the TiO2 films treated at 450°C/1h present tetragonal TiO2-anatase phase as only crystalline phase. Films obtained from TiO2–AcAc–F127 and TiO2–AcAc/AcOH–Brij58 sols present a high but not ordered porosity. Specific surface areas range between 28 and 68m2/g and the total exposed surface (S exp) between 11 and 97cm2/cm2 of sample. The fastest methyl orange degradation, and thus the higher photocatalytic activity, was obtained for 2-layer films of TiO2–AcOH–Brij58 with 390nm with a pore volume of 30% and a surface exposed to illumination of 69cm2/cm2 of sample. These results indicate that photocatalytic activity depends on the type of complexing agent and surfactant, porosity and pore size distribution, and total mass deposited; but mainly on the total surface effectively irradiated with UV photons. coredata.dc:description: Porous TiO2-anatase thin films were obtained by sol–gel method using dip-coating procedure onto glass-slides and silicon wafers in order to study the effect of the porous structure on the photocatalytic properties. Titania sols were synthesized using titanium isopropoxide (TISP) with two types of complexant molecules (acetyl-acetone (AcAc) or acetic acid (AcOH)) and different types of pore-generating agents as: Pluronic F127 (F127), cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), polyethylene glycol hexadecyl ether (Brij56, Brij58). The coatings were characterised by different techniques as grazing X-ray diffraction (GXRD), spectral ellipsometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Maximum thickness around 280nm, and refractive index as low as 1.68 were obtained, indicating that the surfactants allow obtaining porous films. GXRD and TEM analysis confirm the presence of a porous structure but not ordered. TiO2 films obtained from AcAc or AcOH with Brij58 and F127 sols present specific surface areas between 28 and 68m2/g. Photocatalytic activity was studied through the degradation of methyl orange in aqueous solution under UV light exposure. Methyl orange degradation increases with the film thickness up to a maximum value of 470nm, beyond which the efficiency does not further increase. The photocatalytic activity depends on different parameters, such as porosity, film thickness and total surface exposed to illumination.
coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic properties in aqueous solution of porous TiO2-anatase films prepared by sol–gel process
